title-group.article-title: Influence of fuel injection parameters on combustion-induced noise in a small diesel engine

abstract.p: In this paper, the effects of fuel injection parameters on combustion-induced noise in a small single-cylinder direct-injection diesel engine used in a generator set are described. A range of fuel injection parameters, including injection timing and injection quantity, was explored to understand their influence on combustion-induced noise by studying their effect on in-cylinder pressure development. Fourier analysis was performed to understand the effects of changing combustion characteristics on in-cylinder pressure levels in different frequency ranges. In addition, time–frequency analysis was used to understand the changes in the combustion chamber resonance effects under different injection settings. Finally, overall engine noise levels were measured to confirm the changes as predicted by the in-cylinder pressure analysis. Results suggest that retarding main injection has the largest impact on reducing noise. When using split injection, earlier preinjection and larger preinjection quantities tend to result in lower noise.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Engine noise is primarily the result of forces generated within the engine as a consequence of in-cylinder pressure forces induced by combustion, and subsequent mechanical action such as piston slap [1–7]. In this paper, the focus is on noise due to combustion-induced pressure forces in a 296 cc single-cylinder direct-injection (DI) diesel engine. The in-cylinder pressure profile during combustion is dependent on the net heat release rate that, in turn, is influenced by engine geometric parameters and operating conditions [1–4, 8, 9]. The heat release rate in diesel engines is characterized by a rapid premixed-burn phase during which pressure waves are generated and a slower mixing-controlled burn phase [10]. The pressure waves interact with the combustion chamber geometry to produce resonant oscillations of burnt gases [6] and vibrations of the engine structure that are perceived as noise.

Austen and Priede [11] introduced the classical methodology of assessing combustion noise in diesel engines. This methodology is based on a ‘structural attenuation’ curve, which is calculated as the difference between the in-cylinder pressure and the 1/3 octave band spectra of the radiated noise. This approach assumes that the engine structure provides a linear and invariant response to the excitation due to in-cylinder pressure changes. Anderton [12] and Russell and Haworth [13] also carried out studies based on a linear attenuation model of the engine structure for a wide range of engines. Several works have also looked at engine block vibration as a measure of combustion characteristics [14–16]. Recently, Pruvost et al. [17] developed a spectrofilter using only the random portion of the engine signals to separate combustion noise from mechanical noise. In related work, Lee et al. [18] have used multiple input, multiple output (MIMO) procedures to separate combustion-related noise from other engine noise sources with the intention of improving the estimation of the cylinder pressure to radiated sound transfer function.

It is suggested here to study the underlying forces that cause combustion noise. This procedure involves studying the in-cylinder pressure changes caused by varying combustion characteristics under different fuel injection settings. Further, by decomposing the total in-cylinder pressure into its components on the basis of the underlying physical mechanisms [6, 19], pressure changes caused by changing combustion characteristics may be identified and, hence, may be related to changes in overall engine noise emission.

While prior studies have examined noise generation and control in large diesel engines, only a limited number of studies have dealt with small diesel engines [5]. In large engines, typically involving turbocharging and exhaust gas recirculation (EGR), pilot injection and split injection have been shown to be successful strategies for the reduction of radiated noise [20–26]. The present work was intended in part to determine whether these strategies work in small diesel engines without turbocharging or EGR. Furthermore, it will be shown that detailed analysis of the pressure and its frequency spectrum provides insight into the relationships between noise, pressure, and the injection parameters. Thus, the objectives of this paper are as follows:

list-item.p: to study the applicability of injection timing strategies originally recommended for larger multicylinder engines on this small single-cylinder engine;
to ascertain whether in-cylinder pressure data (in particular, time–frequency plots) can be used to predict noise emissions;
to study the effects of varying injection parameters (main injection (MI) timing, preinjection (PI) timing and quantity) on engine noise.

sec.p: Although other engine attributes, such as exhaust emissions and fuel consumption are also affected by fuel injection settings, the focus of this project was on the impact of injection settings on noise.

In section 2, the experimental setup and measurement techniques used in this study are described. The methodology used to identify the various components of in-cylinder pressure and their further analysis is the focus of section 3. In section 4, the results of in-cylinder pressure analysis performed under a range of MI pulse timings are presented. Acoustic measurements are also provided to confirm that the MI settings from the pressure analysis reduce noise. In section 5, results from split injections are presented, including cases for different PI timing and quantity. A summary of the present study is given in section 6, along with conclusions based on the results presented in sections 4 and 5.

sec.title: 2 Experimental Configuration
sec.p: The engine used in the present study was a 296 cc Yanmar L70-AE DEG FRYC single-cylinder, naturally aspirated, DI diesel engine driving a 3 kW electric power unit. The engine runs at 3050 r/min at idle (when there is no electric load) and at 3450 r/min at full 3 kW electric load (accomplished by plugging in several heaters and spotlights).

Fuel injection was performed by means of a common-rail electronic injection system developed at Purdue. A piezoelectric pressure transducer was installed in the cylinder head to measure in-cylinder pressure. The transducer was a Kistler model 6123 A2 transducer with a pressure range up to 200 bar and temperature range up to 350°C. A PCB model 464A charge amplifier was used to convert the charge output of the transducer to a proportional voltage to be input to the dSpace data acquisition system. An AVL 360C optical encoder was mounted on the crankshaft. The encoder had a resolution of 0.6 ° crank angle (CA), and thus generated 1200 pulses per engine cycle. The encoder pulses acted as triggers to acquire the in-cylinder pressure data. Thus, the sampling rate of the in-cylinder pressure, fs, is determined by the encoder resolution (resol.) and engine r/min, according to

Sound pressure measurements were performed in the hemi-anechoic chamber at the Ray W. Herrick Laboratories. A hemi-anechoic chamber environment is considered ideal for engine noise measurement as it simulates the operation of the engine in open space with a reflective floor and no other reflective surfaces. The sound power was measured as per ISO 3744:1994(E) standards by using 10 Brüel and Kjær microphones located on a hemispherical frame around the engine. The radius of the hemisphere was 1.75 m. The locations of the microphones are shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1. The microphones were calibrated using a Brüel and Kjær pistonphone. All the sound power measurements were performed at a sampling frequency of 39.063 kHz, which gives a useful bandwidth of almost 20 kHz; this ensures useful data in the frequency range corresponding to human hearing. A-weighting was applied to all calculated sound power levels to represent the sensitivity of the human ear to sound pressure levels in different frequency ranges.

sec.title: 3 In-Cylinder Pressure Analysis
sec.p: Total in-cylinder pressure is the sum of three components: pseudo-motored pressure, combustion pressure, and combustion chamber resonance pressure [19]. The pseudo-motored signal is attributed to the pressure variation caused only by the compression and expansion of the charge due to piston movement. Clearly, this signal is not influenced by combustion characteristics. The difference between the total pressure and pseudo-motored pressure is referred to as ‘excess’ pressure, which is purely attributed to combustion. The latter signal is mainly composed of the pressure variation due to the burning of fuel and the possible resonant oscillation of burned gases. This decomposition forms the basis for identifying the driving force that contributes to combustion-induced noise and allows the study of changes in the driving force caused by changing fuel injection parameters.

In the present study, the engine had a single cylinder. To measure the pseudo-motored pressure, the fuel injection was turned off while continuing to measure the pressure. By using a signal to indicate the end of fuel injection, the pressure corresponding to the first cycle following the end of fuel injection was separated to ensure no appreciable drop in engine speed. The measurement of the motoring pressure in the first cycle after the end of injection ensures that the heat transfer from walls, which influences the motoring pressure, is not significantly different from that during combustion. This process was repeated several times to obtain an averaged pseudo-motored signal at a given engine speed. This signal was then subtracted from the total in-cylinder pressure to yield the excess pressure signal.
To calculate the ensemble-averaged power spectrum of the in-cylinder pressure components, the following signal processing methodology was used

where Pi(f) and Pi*(f) are the frequency components of the spectrum and their respective complex conjugates corresponding to the ith cycle signal. In this study, an ensemble average of 80 successive engine cycles was considered. Figure 2 shows the time and frequency domain representations of the different components of in-cylinder pressure measured with the engine running at 3450 r/min under full load (3 kW) and with a single-injection pulse timed at 24° before top dead centre (BTDC).

caption.p: (a) Crank-angle domain, and (b) frequency domain representation of in-cylinder pressure components with engine running at 3450 r/min and with MI timed at 24 BTDC

sec.p: It is clearly seen from Fig. 2(b) that the different components of in-cylinder pressure contribute energy in different frequency ranges. At lower frequencies, up to around 300 to 400 Hz, almost all of the energy contribution to the in-cylinder pressure comes from the pseudo-motored signal. Beyond a few hundred Hz, the spectrum is completely dominated by the excess pressure signal. This indicates that combustion noise is significant in a frequency range beyond a few hundred Hz. It is observed that beyond roughly 5 kHz, there are abrupt amplitude peaks in the excess pressure spectrum. The spectral tendency of the signal purely attributed to combustion, without considering combustion chamber resonances, is decreasing [19]. Thus, the amplitude peaks confirm that the excess pressure spectrum beyond a few thousand Hz is due to the resonant vibration of burned gases in the combustion chamber due to combustion pressure gradients. Thus, by high-pass filtering the excess pressure spectrum, the resonance signal can be reconstructed in time, as shown in Fig. 2(a). The cut-off frequency for this filter was chosen by identifying a sharp change in slope of the excess pressure spectrum. The filter was chosen so as to ensure that the only contribution to the resonance signal is from the amplitude peaks in the excess pressure spectrum.

Efforts in the past have shown the non-stationary nature of the combustion chamber resonance signals. Thus, conventional Fourier analysis does not allow effective interpretation of resonance signals. To understand the changes caused to this signal by varying injection parameters, it is useful to perform time–frequency analysis. Any time–frequency analysis is associated with a trade-off between resolution in frequency and in time. Of the various time–frequency analysis techniques described in the literature, it has been found that the Wigner–Ville distribution (WVD) provides reasonably high resolution in both domains. Hence, the WVD was used to analyse the resonance signals in this study. The details of the method are summarized in the appendix.

sec.title: 4 Experimental Results For Single-Injection Pulse
sec.p: Single-injection and two-pulse split injection of the total fuel were evaluated in this study to understand their influence on combustion-induced noise. In all cases, the rail pressure was regulated to 300 bar. When the two-pulse injection was employed, up to 40 per cent of the fuel was delivered during the first pulse, which will be referred to henceforth as ‘preinjection (PI)’. The rest of the fuel was delivered during the second pulse, which will be referred to henceforth as ‘main injection (MI)’. The parameters varied in this study included MI timing, PI timing, and fuel quantity in each pulse. These durations are determined by the fraction of the total quantity of fuel injected during the PI and MI events. Thus, the area under each injection event represents the total fuel quantity injected during that event. Note that the total specified quantity of injected fuel was fixed in this study. However, since ultimate fuelling is set by a speed governor regulating the speed error with a proportional controller, the actual fuel injected depends on the load. In all cases studied here, the full electrical load of 3 kW was applied to the generator.

sec.title: 4.1 In-cylinder pressure analysis under different single-injection pulse timings
sec.p: In these tests, a single-injection (MI) pulse per engine cycle was used. The MI timing was varied from 24 ° to 12 ° CA BTDC, in steps of 3 °. Results presented here were obtained with the engine running at full load of 3 kW at 3450 r/min.

Figure 3 shows the total in-cylinder pressure (in (a)) and its derivative (in (b)) for cases with a single-injection pulse. From Fig. 3(b), it can be seen that as the MI timing is shifted closer to top dead centre (TDC), the peak value of the pressure rise rate, dp/dθ, decreases; this is due to a combination of two factors. When the beginning of injection is delayed, the fuel is injected into higher temperature gas, which results in a shorter ignition delay. A shorter ignition delay reduces the premixed charge available for combustion, thus leading to a more gradual heat release rate. This may be observed in Fig. 4, which shows the net heat release rate for three different MI timings (for clarity). The large dip before the start of combustion may be due to fuel vaporization, but is not completely understood. However, the nature of the heat release rate curve is consistent with that of the pressure derivative curve, showing that retarded injection leads to later and lower peak values of heat release rate and pressure derivative.

caption.p: (a) In-cylinder pressure, and (b) in-cylinder pressure derivative with varying MI timing at full load at 3450 r/min
Variation in heat release rate as MI timing is retarded

sec.p: Another factor in decreasing the pressure derivative for retarded injection is that the pressure rise due to heat release is compensated for by the pressure drop due to volume expansion when the injection timing is retarded towards TDC. As a result, the sharp rise in pressure occurring close to TDC becomes less distinct. With retarded injection timing, the peak pressure rise occurs further into the expansion stroke, and this further reduces the spike in the dp/dθ curve.

Since the rate of change of pressure is the driving force behind the excitation of the engine structure that radiates the combustion-induced noise, the retarding of MI timing closer to TDC can be expected to cause a drop in the amplitude of the in-cylinder pressure spectrum, as can be seen in Fig. 5. Figure 6 shows a comparison of the cumulative in-cylinder pressure level for the five MI timing cases. The cumulative pressure spectrum was calculated by integrating the mean square pressure over the frequency range zero to fs/2, where fs is the sampling frequency. (Thus, the overall mean square pressure is indicated by the high-frequency limit of the cumulative pressure spectrum.) It is seen that with a change in injection timing from 24° to 12° CA, there is a net drop of 7 dB in the total in-cylinder pressure level. (Note that the reference pressure used here was 20 µPa.)

caption.p: In-cylinder pressure spectrum with varying MI timing at full load, 3450 r/min
Cumulative in-cylinder pressure spectrum with varying MI timing at full load, 3450 r/min

sec.p: In all the spectra shown in Fig. 5, the amplitude peaks appear in a frequency range beyond approximately 5 kHz. A high-pass filter with a cut-off frequency of 5 kHz was used in all these cases to isolate the combustion chamber resonance signal. Figure 7 shows the resonance pressure fluctuations, plotted against CA, for different MI timings. It is seen that there exist pressure fluctuations in the vicinity of 230° CA and also around 360° CA. The latter fluctuations can be clearly seen to shift further on the CA axis as the MI timing is moved closer to TDC. In addition, it may be observed that their amplitudes reduce with retarded MI timing. Thus, these features clearly are pressure fluctuations that can be attributed to the resonant excitation of burnt gases. From the high-frequency range in the spectra in Fig. 5, it was seen that moving MI timing closer to TDC reduced the amplitude peaks, and this is corroborated by the signals in Fig. 7. However, the pressure fluctuations occurring at around 230° CA appear stable in their magnitude and their CA location, regardless of MI timing. This may be attributed to closure of the inlet valve that, according to the specifications of the engine under consideration, occurs at 54° after bottom dead centre (BDC), i.e. at 234° CA. Thus, the feature at 230° CA represents the in-cylinder pressure created by the closure of the inlet valve and is possibly mechanical in origin.

Figure 7 clearly shows that under very advanced injection timing, the resonance signals are extremely strong. This is due to the fact that the high rate of pressure rise associated with such a case easily excites the resonant frequencies. In comparison, it may be seen that in the MI 15 and MI 12 cases, the strength of the resonance signal is minimal and, in fact, is similar to, or even lower than that of the fluctuation associated with inlet valve closure.

caption.p: Combustion chamber resonance signal with varying MI timing at full load, 3450 r/min

sec.p: To better understand the pressure fluctuations associated with the two distinct events in the high-pass filtered output signals, time–frequency analysis of these signals was performed by using the WVD. Only the portion of the high-pass filter output signal beyond 250° CA has been considered to ensure that only the resonance signal is analysed. Figure 8(a) shows the time–frequency distribution of resonance signals associated with the MI 24, MI 21 and MI 18 cases at full load (3450 r/min). All magnitudes are in dB. It may be observed that the peak values shift to the right on the CA axis, in accordance with the movement of MI timing closer to TDC. In addition, it may be seen that the peak components shift to lower frequencies as the MI timing is moved closer to TDC. As the MI timing is further retarded, the driving force to excite the resonant frequencies decreases to such an extent that there are no distinct amplitude peaks associated with the resonant pressure fluctuations. This may be seen in Fig. 8(b), which shows the time–frequency distribution for the MI 15 and MI 12 cases. It is evident that the peak magnitudes are much weaker in these two cases.

caption.p: Time–frequency distribution of resonance signal at (a) MI 24, MI 21, MI 18, and (b) MI 15 and MI 12 at full load (3450 r/min)

sec.title: 4.2 Results from acoustic measurements
sec.p: The following results are from the acoustic measurements performed in the hemi-anechoic chamber. The sound pressure measurements were made with 10 microphones arranged as described in section 2. All the data acquisition was performed at a sampling frequency of 39.063 kHz.

Figure 9 shows the 1/3 octave band sound power spectra for the engine running under five different MI timings, at full load (3450 r/min). These are ensemble-averaged spectra of 80 successive engine cycles. On the basis of the combustion pressure spectra in Fig. 5, it would be expected that the sound power levels would drop as the MI timing moves toward TDC. This is clearly evident from the 1/3 octave band spectra in Fig. 9. There is a clear drop in the sound power levels beyond a few hundred Hz, i.e. in the range dominated by combustion-induced noise. The differences seem to be the greatest between around 1 kHz and 10 kHz.

caption.p: 1/3 octave band sound power spectrum with varying MI timing at full load, 3450 r/min

sec.p: An estimate of the changes in total sound power can be made by comparing the net sound power level over the frequency range 0−fs/2, where fs is the sampling frequency. Figure 10 shows the cumulative sound power level for the five MI cases at full load (3450 r/min).

caption.p: Cumulative sound power level (A-weighted) with varying MI timing at full load, 3450 r/min

sec.p: It is clear that the net sound power is almost equal in all cases up to nearly 300 Hz, the frequency range dominated by mechanical noise, which does not depend on combustion characteristics. Differences start appearing only beyond around 300 Hz, clearly indicating the influence of fuel injection strategy on combustion-induced noise. In addition, because of the A-weighting, the greater emphasis placed on components beyond 1 kHz further causes the differences in net sound power to become distinct beyond roughly 1.5 kHz. It is clear that between the extreme cases, i.e. MI 24 and MI 12, there is a difference of 3 dB in the cumulative sound power. This translates to a drop in total sound power by almost 50 per cent.

These results are consistent with the cumulative pressure spectrum plots shown earlier in Fig. 6. As MI is retarded, the level of noise, as well as the cumulative pressure spectrum is reduced. Thus, an analysis of in-cylinder pressure signals is indicative of the magnitude of combustion noise. Since it is easier to fine-tune injection parameters based on in-cylinder pressure signals, all further analysis for split injection was done based on the nature of the in-cylinder pressure signals.

Even though all of the results shown here were for the full-load cases, similar results were also obtained for the idle case (with no electrical load) at 3050 r/min. These idle results also gave consistent trends between in-cylinder pressure analysis and noise measurements.

sec.title: 5 Experimental Results For Split Injection
sec.p: In these tests, two injection pulses per engine cycle, a PI and an MI pulse, were used. Again, the engine was run at full 3 kW electrical load at 3450 r/min. In all cases, the MI was set at 18° CA BTDC as an intermediate setting that would allow the full effects of the PI timing and quantity to be demonstrated.

sec.title: 5.1 Tests with constant PI quantity and varying PI timing
sec.p: Results presented in this section were obtained with the engine running at 3450 r/min with MI timed at 18° CA BTDC, the PI fraction held constant at 40 per cent of total injected quantity, and PI timing varied from 30° to 12° CA before MI timing in steps of 6°.

Figures 11 and 12 show the comparison of excess pressure spectrum and cumulative excess pressure level, respectively, without a PI pulse and for the four cases with varying PI timing. With the PI timing at 48° and 42° CA BTDC, it is clear that the spectral levels in Fig. 11 drop at all frequencies when compared with the spectrum of the case without a PI pulse. The net drop in the pressure level compared to the case without PI in Fig. 12 is almost 3 dB with PI 48 and almost 2 dB with PI 42. When the PI timing is closer to the MI timing, the spectral levels in Fig. 11 are higher than the case without a PI pulse up to 600 Hz, beyond which the levels drop again up to around 4.5 kHz, at which point the spectral levels corresponding to resonance rise sharply. Overall, the two cases with PI 36 and PI 30 in Fig. 12 show a net pressure level within 1 dB of the case without PI.

caption.p: In-cylinder pressure spectrum with MI 18, PI fraction 40 per cent and varying PI timing at 3450 r/min
Cumulative in-cylinder pressure level with MI 18, PI fraction 40 per cent and varying PI timing at 3450 r/min

sec.p: Figure 13 shows the time–frequency distribution of the resonance signal at MI 18 with different PI timings. Clearly, at PI 48, all the modes of the resonant vibration are further weakened relative to the case with no PI. With PI 42, the principal mode is stronger in magnitude, even compared to the case with no PI. As the PI timing is moved closer to the MI timing, at PI 36 and PI 30, the resonance signal grows stronger and the modes of resonant vibration become more distinct.

caption.p: Time–frequency distribution of resonance signal with MI 18, PI fraction 40 per cent and varying PI timing at 3450 r/min

sec.title: 5.2 Tests with constant PI timing and varying PI quantity
sec.p: Results presented in this section were obtained with the engine running at 3450 r/min with the beginning of MI at 18° CA BTDC and PI timing held constant at 48° CA BTDC, while the PI quantities considered were 40 per cent, 30 per cent and 20 per cent of total injected quantity.

Figure 14 shows the in-cylinder pressure derivative as a function of CA for the different cases. Clearly, the peak in the combustion-induced in-cylinder pressure derivative is least in magnitude with the highest PI fraction and increases as the PI fraction is reduced. This may be due to a larger preinjected quantity of fuel undergoing combustion more readily than a smaller preinjected fuel fraction.

caption.p: In-cylinder pressure derivative with MI 18, PI 48 and varying PI quantity at 3450 r/min

sec.p: This trend is evidenced by the in-cylinder pressure spectra in Fig. 15. Clearly, the spectrum corresponding to the case with the highest PI fraction is lower than with just the MI pulse. The spectral levels rise as the PI fraction is reduced. This is also corroborated by the cumulative pressure levels in Fig. 16.

caption.p: In-cylinder pressure spectrum with MI 18, PI 48 and varying PI quantity at 3450 r/min
Cumulative in-cylinder pressure spectrum with MI 18, PI 48 and varying PI quantity at 3450 r/min

sec.p: Figure 17 shows the time–frequency distribution of the resonance signal for cases of varying PI quantity. It may be seen that the strength of resonant oscillations progressively increases as the PI quantity is reduced.

caption.p: Time–frequency distribution of resonance signal with MI 18, PI 48 and varying PI quantity at 3450 r/min

sec.title: 6 Conclusions
sec.p: In the present work, the influence of fuel injection parameters on combustion noise was studied based on analysis of combustion-induced, in-cylinder pressure in a small, single-cylinder diesel engine. Studies were performed initially considering one (main) injection pulse per engine cycle. Injection timings covered a wide CA range from 24° to 12° CA BTDC. Further studies were performed using a split injection strategy, in which one PI pulse and one MI pulse were considered. In these tests, cases with varying PI timing and varying PI quantity were considered.

A careful look at the in-cylinder pressure signals under different injection timings showed that the greatest change in combustion-induced, in-cylinder pressure levels occurred when changing the MI timings. When advancing MI timing away from TDC, the combustion pressure increased, with the highest combustion pressure levels occurring for the most advanced injection timing. Increased combustion pressure would be expected to generate more engine noise, as confirmed by the corresponding sound power measurements in the hemi-anechoic chamber.

A time–frequency analysis using the WVD was performed to isolate the resonance portion of the in-cylinder pressure signal. This analysis of the combustion chamber resonance also showed that MI timing has the greatest influence on the magnitude of resonant oscillations and hence combustion noise quality.

When a PI pulse was used in addition to the MI pulse, it was noticed that the greatest drop in combustion pressure levels occurred in cases with the greatest separation between the two injection pulses and with a relatively high PI quantity. It must be noted that these observed trends are valid for the range of parameters studied here. With an excessive separation between the two pulses, the PI may not have any influence on in-cylinder pressure. In addition, the PI quantity beyond a certain higher limit may only cause the effective injection timing to become very advanced, and hence may reverse the trend of decreasing in-cylinder pressure levels.
The present study demonstrates that injection timing and split injection can be used effectively in a small naturally aspirated DI diesel engine to reduce noise.
